citations.narrative:
There are multiple sharp points present in the outdoor enclosure for ostriches. Three shade structures have metal wire
strands of various length (approximately 1-2 feet long) hanging down from the roof. Presence of sharp points in bird
enclosures may cause painful injury or discomfort to the animals. Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed
so that there are no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds. Corrected at time of inspection.
Correct from this date forward of 21 May 2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The perch structures in the chicken enclosure have some accumulation of fecal material on the vertical surfaces of
support beams below the dowel perches. Approximately 5 birds appear to have lightly soiled feathers on the head, chest
and/or back regions. The facility representative stated the deep cleaning schedule for the enclosure is twice yearly and
then accompanied by weekly chlorhexidine spraying of surfaces. Insufficient cleaning can lead to disease hazards, soiling
of animals, insects, pests and odors. Excreta and food waste must be removed from within, under, and around the
primary enclosure as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation and soiling of birds contained therein.
Correct by 30 May 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There are multiple sharp points present in the outdoor enclosure for ostriches. Three shade structures have metal wire 
strands of various length (approximately 1-2 feet long) hanging down from the roof. Presence of sharp points in bird 
enclosures may cause painful injury or discomfort to the animals. Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed 
so that there are no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds. Corrected at time of inspection. 
 
Correct from this date forward of 21 May 2025. 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The perch structures in the chicken enclosure have some accumulation of fecal material on the vertical surfaces of 
support beams below the dowel perches. Approximately 5 birds appear to have lightly soiled feathers on the head, chest 
and/or back regions. The facility representative stated the deep cleaning schedule for the enclosure is twice yearly and 
then accompanied by weekly chlorhexidine spraying of surfaces. Insufficient cleaning can lead to disease hazards, soiling 
of animals, insects, pests and odors. Excreta and food waste must be removed from within, under, and around the 
primary enclosure as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation and soiling of birds contained therein. 
 
Correct by 30 May 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
